content: The part of the wall is somewhat tangled, that is, somewhat disordered, it should be explained what the height of the walls of all the rooms is and be able to relate it effectively.

Hey. I just got this in a clash an won with 16%, 5/6 people got 0%, some just left the clash straight away.

It's quite a hard one. Combining a lot of string manipulation with non-trivial, conditional calculations that then need to be formatted with the dreaded 1000's separator (my least favourite part to solve, haha).

Also, it's a bit unclear what you mean by 'shown to 2 decimal places' as this could mean truncate or round, or even ceil.
Test 2 is particularly hard for this since:
9.25*0.9*2*(8+11)*1.5 = 474.525
Which you round to 474.53, but sprintf (at least in Ruby) rounds it to $474.52.

It took me about 10 minutes just to solve the base problem and start working on 1000's separators, then when I started getting errors (forgot to multiply by costPer in walls condition), I had no time to debug.

I recommend removing the formatting for the answer and just allowing it to be a rounded float.
Also, just giving the height as a float rather than a string. These seem like unnecessary hurdles to make an already tricky challenge even harder.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This problem is not that difficult and easy to understand.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great idea, very exciting to solve

"followed by the floor dimensions, in the format of an integer x another integer"
The integers could be named A & B (or W & L we)
Then add them to the Constraints section (min max)

The 10% note on walls is quite subtle
This looks fun. Could be a bit shorter. But it feels like a practicle real world calculation on the other hand.

Output section
* Please mention that the answer should be shown to 2 decimal places.

Input section
* Suggest to simplify Line 1 to just the height (e.g. "8.5" instead of "8.5 feet tall", and mention the measurement unit in the description, as I think there is enough parsing to do in the renovation detail lines.

Or, if you'd rather not to modify the input, please indicate that the format of the string is the height (a float/double) followed by "{{ feet tall}}".

* Please mention the measurement unit of the dimensions.

* Please mention the cost is always prefixed with {{$}}.

* It's a bit confusing to me... So "floor dimensions" are provided no matter the upgrade work is done to walls or floors. Do I have to figure out "wall dimensions" myself? Do I have to assume the number of walls to upgrade? 1? 2? 3? 4? Do I always assume walls and floors are rectangular? (My bedroom does not have rectangular walls and floors.) It may be better to explain more in Goal section.

Thanks.
Please always write a reason for your approval or rejection of a contribution.

Thank you.

To clarify, I wrote "float/double" because "float" is the term used in CG documentation but "double" is the term used in your description of "cost-per-square-foot of the materials"... I was hesitant about which word to use back then. You need not state both words in the description of Input Line 1; one of them is sufficient ðŸ˜‰
